subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Group
msgSnippet: Hi, I m new to this group and thought perhaps its activity had died down. So it was good to hear from both Sidney and Paige. I ve kept a very simple journal in
messageBody:
Hi,

 

I’m new to this group and thought perhaps its activity had died down. So it was good to hear from both Sidney and Paige.

 

I’ve kept a very simple journal in Quikscript off and on for some time. I’m hoping that some correspondence in Quikscript will improve my skills a bit and give me a “feel” for a better way to write in English.

 

In response to some of Paige’s comments, I have fooled around making some very crude computer fonts using an inexpensive program called Font Creator Program (FCP). With this program, I’ve had difficulty designing the characters so that the cursor went to its intended and usual position. Perhaps this is what ails Jerome.

 

Paige, can you tell me which characters you think are malformed? I could have a go at improving them - - - but please do not get your hopes very high. Whoever made Jerome is better at making fonts than I am.

 

If anyone would care to, I’d like to carry on some short, simple, correspondence in Quikscript. So as a start, I’ve attached a Word document with a couple of sentences in Quikscript using Jerome. Despite Paige’s comments, I can’t even read my own Quikscript with Jerome unless I keep the characters from running together. I do this by going to Word’s

 

Format/Font/Character Spacing/Spacing menu and expanding by about 1.2 points.

 

Best Wishes,

 

 

e-mail: ed.gaddy@...

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Sidney Tanaban [mailto:sidban2@...]
Sent: Monday, February 11, 2002 6:59 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group

 

Hi
I saw your message.  I know both Shaws and Kwikskript but have not seen any Kwikskrit on internet.  I would appreciate you letting me know if there is.  Like you I have not had much opportunity to read it and that is as important as writing it.  One way is by letter and I tried somewhat to promote that but no one was interested.  Like you I am not software savvy and have no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  Please keep in touch if anyone is capable of doing something in this area.

Sid


On Mon, 11 February 2002, "pgabhart" wrote:

>
> Welcome to all new members of the group and hello again to those who
> have been members for awhile.  Life has not left me much time in
> recent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am trying to correct
> that to some degree now.  I am still having a little trouble with my
> e-mail -- my network at my office is not currently operational -- so
> do not despair if I do not respond to an e-mail as quickly as you
> would have liked.  I will respond eventually.
>
> I have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Quikscript,for roughly 26
> years.  I have only had an e-mail from one other person who has been
> aware of the alphabet for that length of time, and he seems to
> alternate between Read's Alphabet and Shavian.  If you or anyone you
> know of has been using it for an extended period of time, let us hear
> from you.
>
> I am a firm believer in the utility of Read's Alphabet as well as its
> viability as an alternative alphabet that could help people in their
> daily lives just as Kingsley Read suggested in the Quikscript Manual.
>
> A little background on myself:  I am an attorney in private practice,
> who considers himself semi-computer literate.  By this I mean I am
> not knowledgable about specialized areas of computer science, such as
> designing fonts from scratch.  On the other hand, I am not afraid to
> open up my CPU to add hardware, and I remember what a DOS command
> is.  Hence, the semi-literate designation.  I bring this up because
> there are computer skills that I do not have, nor do I have the time
> to learn them in the near future, that would greatly enhance this
> site.  I do not doubt there are people in this group who already
> possess some of these skills and who, with a modest investment of
> time, could help us to turn this site into an attractive spot to
> attract more Read's Alphabet users.
>
> To give you some idea of what I am talking about:  Here are several
> things I would like to see appear on this site.
> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript manual.  It is not copyrighted so there
> is no legal prohibition I am aware of that would prevent us from
> posting it.
> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  These should be varying
> lengths and levels of complexity.  They could be original or copies
> of literary works in the public domain.
> 3.  A practice area for people to write back and forth to each other
> in Read's Alphabet to gain experience in reading other people's
> script.  I must admit that even after years of occasional use, I am
> not as fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading roman. 
> Practice makes perfect, after all.  I read roman everyday.  I cannot
> say that about Read's Alphabet.  It is hard to get practice when the
> only person that knows the script is yourself.  I know by experience,
> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's Alphabet,
> but the internet gives us the chance to reach people from around the
> globe who are intellectually curious.  The internet gives us an
> inexpensive platform that could spread the word to others.
> 4.  Have all explanatory notes written in both roman and Read's
> Alphabet just as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.
>
> For computer use we have the "Jerome" font, which was created about
> fifteen months ago.  I am excited about this as it gives us the
> opportunity to use the half-letters, which I found such an
> interesting facet of Read's Alphabet in handwriting as they provide
> word shapes that are more distinctive than those written with the
> full letters as in Junior Quikscript.  Jerome lets us use this
> feature in internet correspondence and teaching.  Jerome also shows
> that the letters can be joined in a "cursive" manner even
> in "printing" and remain graceful and attractive as opposed to the 
> detached and stilted Shavian.
>
> On the other hand, Jerome was the work of a person new to computer
> fonts, and it is not perfect.  I am confident that someone familiar
> with computer fonts could redesign Jerome to improve it and make it
> even easier to use while maintaining its basic style.  I believe some
> of the letters need additional work to bring them closer to their
> appearance in the Quikscript manual.  Another problem is that
> sometimes the cursor position does not appear where the next letter
> will be inserted.  This can be confusing.  And why does it only
> happen sometimes?  I think this problem is related to the use of half-
> letters, but I am not sure of this.
>
> I am interested in hearing your thoughts on this and any other
> matters connected to the use and spread of Read's Alphabet.  Thanks
> for taking the time to read this long post.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
>
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> Read_Alphabet-unsubscribe@egroups.com
>
> 
>

Hi,

I'm new to this group and thought perhaps its activity had died down. So it
was good to hear from both Sidney and Paige.

I've kept a very simple journal in Quikscript off and on for some time. I'm
hoping that some correspondence in Quikscript will improve my skills a bit
and give me a "feel" for a better way to write in English.

In response to some of Paige's comments, I have fooled around making some
very crude computer fonts using an inexpensive program called Font Creator
Program (FCP). With this program, I've had difficulty designing the
characters so that the cursor went to its intended and usual position.
Perhaps this is what ails Jerome.

Paige, can you tell me which characters you think are malformed? I could
have a go at improving them - - - but please do not get your hopes very
high. Whoever made Jerome is better at making fonts than I am.

If anyone would care to, I'd like to carry on some short, simple,
correspondence in Quikscript. So as a start, I've attached a Word document
with a couple of sentences in Quikscript using Jerome. Despite Paige's
comments, I can't even read my own Quikscript with Jerome unless I keep the
characters from running together. I do this by going to Word's

Format/Font/Character Spacing/Spacing menu and expanding by about 1.2
points.

Best Wishes,


e-mail: ed.gaddy@...
phone:  301 390 5115

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in'>=
<font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span

<p c=
lass=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in'><tt><font size=3D2 color=3Dblac=
k
face=3D"Courier New"><span style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier=
 New";
color:black'>Hi</span></font></tt><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=
=3D"Courier New"><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";=
mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:black'><br>
<tt>I saw your mes=
sage.  I know both Shaws and Kwikskript but have not
seen any Kwikskri=
t on internet.  I would appreciate you letting me know if
there is.&nb=
sp; Like you I have not had much opportunity to read it and that is
as impo=
rtant as writing it.  One way is by letter and I tried somewhat to
pro=
mote that but no one was interested.  Like you I am not software savvy=

and have no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  Please keep i=
n
touch if anyone is capable of doing something in this area.</tt><br>
<br>=

<tt>Sid</tt><br>
<br>
<br>
<tt>On Mon, 11 February 2002, "pgabhart&qu=
ot; wrote:</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> Welcome to all new mem=
bers of the group and hello again to those who </tt><br>
<tt>> have been=
 members for awhile.  Life has not left me much time in </tt><br>
<tt>=
> recent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am trying to
corr=
ect </tt><br>
<tt>> that to some degree now.  I am still having a l=
ittle trouble with
my </tt><br>
<tt>> e-mail -- my network at my office =
is not currently operational -- so </tt><br>
<tt>> do not despair if I d=
o not respond to an e-mail as quickly as you </tt><br>
<tt>> would have =
liked.  I will respond eventually.</tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>&gt=
; I have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Quikscript,for roughly 26 </tt><br=
>
<tt>> years.  I have only had an e-mail from one other person who=
 has
been </tt><br>
<tt>> aware of the alphabet for that length of time,=
 and he seems to </tt><br>
<tt>> alternate between Read's Alphabet and S=
havian.  If you or anyone
you </tt><br>
<tt>> know of has been usin=
g it for an extended period of time, let us hear </tt><br>
<tt>> from yo=
u.</tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> I am a firm believer in the utility=
 of Read's Alphabet as well as its </tt><br>
<tt>> viability as an alter=
native alphabet that could help people in their </tt><br>
<tt>> daily li=
ves just as Kingsley Read suggested in the Quikscript Manual.</tt><br>
<tt>=
> </tt><br>
<tt>> A little background on myself:  I am an attorn=
ey in private
practice, </tt><br>
<tt>> who considers himself semi-compu=
ter literate.  By this I mean I
am </tt><br>
<tt>> not knowledgable=
 about specialized areas of computer science, such as </tt><br>
<tt>> de=
signing fonts from scratch.  On the other hand, I am not afraid
to </t=
t><br>
<tt>> open up my CPU to add hardware, and I remember what a DOS c=
ommand </tt><br>
<tt>> is.  Hence, the semi-literate designation.&n=
bsp; I bring this up
because </tt><br>
<tt>> there are computer skills t=
hat I do not have, nor do I have the time </tt><br>
<tt>> to learn them =
in the near future, that would greatly enhance this </tt><br>
<tt>> site=
.  I do not doubt there are people in this group who already </tt><br>=

<tt>> possess some of these skills and who, with a modest investment of=
 </tt><br>
<tt>> time, could help us to turn this site into an attractiv=
e spot to </tt><br>
<tt>> attract more Read's Alphabet users.</tt><br>
<=
tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> To give you some idea of what I am talking about=
:  Here are
several </tt><br>
<tt>> things I would like to see appe=
ar on this site.</tt><br>
<tt>> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript manual=
.  It is not copyrighted
so there </tt><br>
<tt>> is no legal prohi=
bition I am aware of that would prevent us from </tt><br>
<tt>> posting =
it.</tt><br>
<tt>> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  Thes=
e should be
varying </tt><br>
<tt>> lengths and levels of complexity.&nb=
sp; They could be original or
copies </tt><br>
<tt>> of literary works i=
n the public domain.</tt><br>
<tt>> 3.  A practice area for people =
to write back and forth to each
other </tt><br>
<tt>> in Read's Alphabet=
 to gain experience in reading other people's </tt><br>
<tt>> script.&nb=
sp; I must admit that even after years of occasional use, I
am </tt><br>
<t=
t>> not as fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading
roman.&n=
bsp; </tt><br>
<tt>> Practice makes perfect, after all.  I read rom=
an everyday. 
I cannot </tt><br>
<tt>> say that about Read's Alphab=
et.  It is hard to get practice when
the </tt><br>
<tt>> only perso=
n that knows the script is yourself.  I know by
experience, </tt><br>
=
<tt>> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's Alphabe=
t, </tt><br>
<tt>> but the internet gives us the chance to reach people =
from around the </tt><br>
<tt>> globe who are intellectually curious.&nb=
sp; The internet gives us an </tt><br>
<tt>> inexpensive platform that c=
ould spread the word to others.</tt><br>
<tt>> 4.  Have all explana=
tory notes written in both roman and Read's </tt><br>
<tt>> Alphabet jus=
t as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.</tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br=
>
<tt>> For computer use we have the "Jerome" font, which was
=
created about </tt><br>
<tt>> fifteen months ago.  I am excited abo=
ut this as it gives us the </tt><br>
<tt>> opportunity to use the half-l=
etters, which I found such an </tt><br>
<tt>> interesting facet of Read'=
s Alphabet in handwriting as they provide </tt><br>
<tt>> word shapes th=
at are more distinctive than those written with the </tt><br>
<tt>> full=
 letters as in Junior Quikscript.  Jerome lets us use this </tt><br>
<=
tt>> feature in internet correspondence and teaching.  Jerome also
=
shows </tt><br>
<tt>> that the letters can be joined in a "cursive&=
quot; manner even </tt><br>
<tt>> in "printing" and remain gra=
ceful and attractive as opposed
to the  </tt><br>
<tt>> detached an=
d stilted Shavian.</tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> On the other hand, =
Jerome was the work of a person new to computer </tt><br>
<tt>> fonts, a=
nd it is not perfect.  I am confident that someone
familiar </tt><br>
=
<tt>> with computer fonts could redesign Jerome to improve it and make i=
t </tt><br>
<tt>> even easier to use while maintaining its basic style.&=
nbsp; I believe
some </tt><br>
<tt>> of the letters need additional work=
 to bring them closer to their </tt><br>
<tt>> appearance in the Quikscr=
ipt manual.  Another problem is that </tt><br>
<tt>> sometimes the =
cursor position does not appear where the next letter </tt><br>
<tt>> wi=
ll be inserted.  This can be confusing.  And why does it
only </t=
t><br>
<tt>> happen sometimes?  I think this problem is related to =
the use of
half-</tt><br>
<tt>> letters, but I am not sure of this.</tt>=
<br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> I am interested in hearing your thoughts o=
n this and any other </tt><br>
<tt>> matters connected to the use and sp=
read of Read's Alphabet. 
Thanks </tt><br>
<tt>> for taking the tim=
e to read this long post.</tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<t=
t>> Paige Gabhart</tt><br>
